item.label: Cerebral sulci, Lateral
item.name: Lateral sulcus
item.description: The lateral fissure or sulcus is AKA the Sylvian fissure. It is a long, deep sulcus on the lateral aspect of each cerebral hemisphere that separates the frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe.  The main portion of the fissure is sometimes referred to as the posterior ramus.  Anteriorly, the fissure branches to subdivide the inferior frontal gyrus; anterior horizontal and anterior ascending rami delineate the orbital, triangular and opercular portions of the inferior frontal gyrus.  The cortex known as the insula is located deep within this sulcus and the transverse temporal gyri (auditory cortex) is located on the temporal lobe aspect of the fissure.

item.label: Cerebral fissure, Longitudinal
item.name: Med. longitudinal fissure
item.description: The longitudinal cerebral fissure is AKA the median longitudinal fissure. it is a deep midline fissure located between the two cerebral hemispheres.  The cerebral falx (a dural reflection) extends into this fissure.

item.label: Frontal lobe
item.name: Frontal lobe
item.description: The frontal lobe is the most anterior lobe of the cerebral hemisphere. It includes primary motor cortex, premotor cortex, supplementary motor cortex, frontal eye fields, prefrontal cortex and orbital cortex. Via connections with the dorsomedial nucleus of thalamus and elsewhere, it is associated with the limbic system.

item.label: Orbital gyri
item.name: Orbital gyri
item.description: Orbital gyri are located on the ventral surface of the frontal lobe.  In this location, they are positioned above the orbits of the skull.

item.label: Gyrus rectus
item.name: Gyrus rectus
item.description: The gyrus rectus is a slender, straight gyrus on the orbital surface of the frontal lobe.  It is located just medial to the position of the olfactory bulb and olfactory tract. It is involved in limbic system circuits.

item.label: Olfactory sulcus
item.name: Olfactory sulcus
item.description: The olfactory sulcus is located on the orbital surface of the frontal lobe, immediately lateral to the gyrus rectus.  The olfactory bulb and tract lie in this sulcus.

item.label: Olfactory bulb
item.name: Olfactory bulb
item.description: The olfactory bulb is the expanded rostral end of the olfactory tract.  It is located in the frontal cranial fossa directly above the cribriform plate. It receives olfactory input from the very thin axons (Cranial Nerve I) of receptor neurons in the olfactory epithelium of the nasal cavity. It projects via the olfactory tract to olfactory (piriform) cerebral cortex as well as the amygdala.

item.label: Olfactory tract
item.name: Olfactory tract
item.description: Located on the ventral surface of the orbital gyri of the frontal lobe, the olfactory tract consists of the axons of the olfactory bulb neurons. These axons branch into the medial and lateral olfactory stria forming the olfactory trigone; they will terminate in the olfactory (piriform) cerebral cortex as well as the amygdala.

item.label: Olfactory trigone
item.name: Olfactory trigone
item.description: The olfactory trigone is a small triangular area in front of the anterior perforated substance on the inferior aspect of the brain.

item.label: Anterior perforated substance
item.name: Ant. perforated substanc
item.description: The anterior perforated substance is located on the inferior surface of the forebrain between the orbital gyri and the optic chiasm. Numerous small blood vessels branching from the anterior and middle cerebral arteries (lenticulostriate) penetrate this area to supply adjacent brain structures. These penetrating vessels are the source of the perforated appearance.

item.label: Temporal lobe
item.name: Temporal lobe
item.description: The temporal lobe is the most inferior lobe of the cerebral hemispheres.  It is located below the lateral sulcus and anterior to the occipital lobe. Important structures within the temporal lobe include: auditory sensory and association cortex, part of the posterior language cortex, visual and higher-order association cortex, primary and association olfactory cortex, amygdala, hippocampus and the inferior or temporal horn of the lateral ventricle.

item.label: Parahippocampal gyrus
item.name: Parahippocampal gyrus
item.description: The parahippocampal gyrus is the most medial gyrus on the ventral aspect of the temporal lobe. The hippocampus is cortex that is rolled up inside the parahippocampal gyrus. The rostral portion of this gyrus is the entorhinal cortex.

item.label: Uncus
item.name: Uncus
item.description: The uncus is a bulge on the anterior aspect of the parahippocampal gyrus caused by the underlying amygdala. it can herniate through the tentorial notch in the event of increased intracranial pressure due to a supratentorial space-occupying lesion.

item.label: Inferior temporal sulcus
item.name: Inferior temporal sulcus
item.description: The inferior temporal sulcus is located on the inferior aspect of the temporal lobe where it separates the inferior temporal gyrus from the fusiform (occipitotemporal) gyrus.

item.label: Inferior temporal gyrus
item.name: Inferior temporal gyrus
item.description: The inferior temporal gyrus is the most inferior of the three gyri on the lateral aspect of the temporal lobe. It is part of visual association cortex.

item.label: Collateral sulcus
item.name: Collateral sulcus
item.description: The collateral sulcus is a deep sulcus on the inferior or ventral surface of the temporal lobe, separating the occipitotemporal or fusiform gyrus from the parahippocampal gyrus.

item.label: Occipitotemporal gyrus
item.name: Occipitotemporal gyrus
item.description: The occipitotemporal gyrus is AKA the fusiform gyrus. This long gyrus on the ventral aspect of the temporal lobe extends from near the uncus to the occipital lobe. It is bounded laterally by the inferior temporal gyrus and medially by the parahippocampal gyrus.

item.label: Diencephalon
item.name: Diencephalon
item.description: Developmentally, the diencephalon and telencephalon are derived from the most anterior aspect of the developing neural tube, i.e. the prosencephalon. It includes the thalamus, hypothalamus, epithalamus and subthalamus. The retina, optic nerve and tract and neurohypophysis are also considered to be part of the diencephalon since they are formed as outgrowths from the diencephalon.

item.label: Hypothalamus
item.name: Hypothalamus
item.description: The hypothalamus is the most inferior of the four divisions of the diencephalon. While quite small, it has multiple important functions. It is the central control center for the autonomic nervous system, part of the limbic system, exerts a powerful influence on pituitary function and generally is responsible for maintaining homeostasis. It consists of multiple nuclei organized into three regions: anterior (suprachiasmatic, supraoptic and paraventricular), tuberal (dorsomedial, ventromedial and arcuate) and posterior (mammillary and posterior).

item.label: Mammillary bodies
item.name: Mammillary body
item.description: The mammillary bodies are part of the posterior hypothalamus.  They appear from the ventral view of the brain as a pair of rounded elevations. Primary circuitry involves input from the hippocampus via the fornix and output to the anterior nucleus of thalamus via the mammillothalamic tract. They are part of the Papez circuitry of the limbic system.

item.label: Median eminence
item.name: Midian eminence
item.description: The median eminence is a surface elevation in the mid-portion of the tuber cinereum of the hypothalamus. It is located between the optic chiasm and mammillary bodies on the ventral aspect of the hypothalamus. The infundibulum or stalk of the pituitary extends from the midpoint of this area to the posterior lobe of the pituitary.  The medial eminence is one of the circumventricular organs and is the site of release of hypothalamic hormones into the hypothalamic-hypophyseal portal system.

item.label: Tuber cinereum
item.name: Tuber cinereum
item.description: The tuber cinereum is a region of the hypothalamic gray matter that includes the median eminence and the base of the infundibular stalk. It is bounded by the optic chiasm, optic tracts and the anterior edge of the mammillary bodies. Important in the hypothalamic regulation of the adenohypophysis.

item.label: Visual pathway
item.name: Visual pathway
item.description: The entire visual pathway begins in the retina and terminates in the calcarine cortex of the occipital lobe.  The components of the pathway are the optic nerve, optic chiasm, optic tract, lateral geniculate nucleus and optic radiations.

item.label: Optic nerve
item.name: Optic n.
item.description: The Optic nerve or Cranial Nerve II consists of the axons of ganglion cells in the retina. The optic nerve axons will travel through the optic tract and then synapse in the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus as well as in the pretectum.  Between the optic nerve and lateral geniculate nucleus, the nerve fibers from the nasal half of the retina cross the midline in the optic chiasm and then enter the optic tract; the nerve fibers from the temporal half of the retina do not cross, but enter the optic tract directly.

item.label: Optic chiasm
item.name: Optic chiasm
item.description: The optic chiasm is a midline structure that consists of the axons of retinal neurons located in the nasal half of each retina.  These nerve fibers travel first in the optic nerve and then cross in midline of the optic chiasm so that the input from the nasal retina of each eye (temporal visual field) projects to the contralateral optic tract and beyond in the visual pathway. Input from the temporal retina (nasal visual field) does NOT cross in the chiasm but projects through the ipsilateral visual pathway.  This partial crossing of the visual input is essential for binocular vision.

item.label: Optic tract
item.name: Optic tract
item.description: The Optic tract consists of optic nerve axons that serve the contralateral visual field.  These axons originate in the ipsilateral temporal retina and contralateral nasal retina and terminate in the lateral geniculate nucleus as well as the pretectal area.

item.label: Midbrain
item.name: Midbrain
item.description: The midbrain is AKA the mesencephalon. Within its parts (tectum, tegmentum, substantia nigra and cerebral crus or basis pedunculi), it contains cranial nerve nuclei, all of the clinically important ascending and descending tracts, etc. It is traversed by the cerebral aqueduct or aqueduct of Sylvius. It originates developmentally from the mesencephalon.

item.label: Tectum
item.name: Tectum
item.description: The tectum is that portion of the midbrain located above the cerebral aqueduct.  It includes the superior and inferior colliculi which are AKA the quadrigeminal bodies.

item.label: Tegmentum
item.name: Tegmentum
item.description: The tegmentum is that portion of the midbrain that lies between the cerebral aqueduct and the crus cerebri.  It includes the major ascending sensory tracts (medial lemniscus, spinothalamic), the red nucleus and the substantia nigra.

item.label: Substantia nigra
item.name: Substantia nigra
item.description: The substantia nigra is a large band-like nucleus in the midbrain located between the crus cerebri and the red nuclei of the tegmentum. It has two parts: 1) a compact portion consisting of closely packed dopaminergic neurons filled with neuromelanin pigment. These neurons project to the striatum & are the ones damaged in Parkinson disease; 2) a reticular portion consisting of loosely packed neurons that receive input from the striatum and project to the thalamus.

item.label: Cerebral crus
item.name: Basis pedunculi
item.description: The cerebral crus is AKA the crus cerebri or the basis pedunculi. This most ventral or inferior aspect of the paired cerebral peduncles contains motor axons originating primarily in the cerebral cortex. The bulk of the cerebral crus is made up of the corticospinal, corticobulbar and corticopontine tract fibers that have left the cerebral cortex, traveled through the internal capsule and will terminate in the spinal cord and brain stem.

item.label: Oculomotor nerve
item.name: Oculomotor n.
item.description: The third or oculomotor cranial nerve provides motor innervation to the ipsilateral medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, inferior oblique and levator palapebrae muscles that move the eye. It also includes parasympathetic fibers that terminate in the ipsilateral ciliary ganglion; post-ganglionic fibers from the ciliary ganglion innervate the constrictors of the pupil and the ciliary muscles.

item.label: Cerebral aqueduct
item.name: Cerebral aqueduct
item.description: The cerebral aqueduct is AKA the cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius.  It is a narrow channel within the midbrain through which cerebrospinal fluid flows from the third ventricle into the fourth ventricle.
